I have mild Asperger's and didn't know until I was in my 30s. I was smart, skipped two grades, and had to be told by my parents when I was 10 or 11 that looking people in the eye was expected. I can do that, but I force myself to do it, and I look away as soon as possible. People think I'm being dodgy, and some people used to think I was snobby or don't like them, but the only way I can explain my demeanor that I am not comfortable conveying my soul to another person through my gaze.It would have been nice if my parents or my teachers knew about and identified my Asperger's when I was young. Knowledge and education about it has liberated me, and I don't live with the stigma that I am just an antisocial person. I am, thankfully, lucid enough to talk openly about my Asperger's and I don't let it hinder me or others' perception of me anymore.It's not just other kids who need to understand autism, it's teachers, parents, and the person who is autistic!  Do not underestimate what your autistic child or student can understand and do.  They might not be able (or willing) to communicate like you do, but they can do and see things you cannot.  Researchers need to bridge autistic giftedness to the rest of society.
